p.span: Apple‚Äôs top AI architect, Ruoming Pang, is jumping ship to join Meta‚Äôs ambitious Superintelligence Labs, just as the Cupertino giant‚Äôs models struggle to impress.
Is this a critical blow to Apple‚Äôs AI plans? And could Meta‚Äôs talent grab shift the balance in the AI race?
Meta poaches Apple‚Äôs head of AI
Jack Dorsey‚Äôs ‚ÄòBitchat‚Äô messaging app
The American version of TikTok
OpenAI‚Äôs military-grade lab lockdown
Quick hits on other major tech news
Image source: Ideogram/The Rundown
In a major win for Meta‚Äôs expanding AI ambitions, Apple‚Äôs head of AI models, Ruoming Pang, is leaving Cupertino to join Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs newly launched AI division, Superintelligence Labs,
At Apple, Pang played a key role in developing foundation models powering Apple Intelligence and the upcoming Siri update.
His exit comes amid mounting troubles at Apple over its AI models, which have lagged behind the offerings of OpenAI, Anthropic, and even Meta itself.
Meta has been aggressively recruiting top AI talent for its Superintelligence Labs, led by Scale AI‚Äôs Alexandr Wang and former GitHub CEO Nat Friedman.
Apple has reportedly explored licensing third-party AI models, such as those from OpenAI or Google, to supplement its technology.

Meta‚Äôs aggressive hiring spree ‚Äî offering multimillion-dollar salaries ‚Äî has become a major draw for top talent, while Apple‚Äôs AI division is reportedly grappling with internal friction. Pang‚Äôs departure could spark a broader wave of exits, as other key players may question Apple‚Äôs AI strategy and its ability to stay competitive.
Image source: Steve Jurvetson/Wikimedia Commons
Block CEO and Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey
on X that he spent his weekend building a new messaging app called Bitchat, which he described as a peer-to-peer chat service that operates entirely over Bluetooth mesh networks.
The app, available in beta via TestFlight (which quickly maxed out its user limit), doesn‚Äôt require the internet, phone numbers, or email addresses to use it.
It‚Äôs designed for encrypted, ephemeral communication that can persist even when traditional networks are blocked or censored.¬†
Each device acts as both a client and a relay, allowing messages to ‚Äúhop‚Äù from device to device, extending the range far beyond standard Bluetooth limits.
The app supports password-protected group chats, and it features mechanisms like timing randomization to further obfuscate user activity.

Dorsey, a proponent of decentralized tech like Bluesky and Nostr, called Bitchat an experiment in mesh networking, store-and-forward messaging, and end-to-end encryption. Wi-Fi Direct support is coming, enabling even richer peer-to-peer sharing offline.
Image source: Ideogram/The Rundown
TikTok is
building a U.S.-only version of its app as pressure mounts on Chinese parent ByteDance, which is targeting a Sept. 5 launch ‚Äî well ahead of the March 2026 shutdown deadline for the current version.
The new app is expected to operate independently from ByteDance‚Äôs global infrastructure, with all U.S. user data migrated to U.S.-based servers.
The report follows President Trump‚Äôs announcement that talks with China on a TikTok sale are starting this week, with a deal being ‚Äúpretty much‚Äù in place.
U.S. users will need to download a new app, and it‚Äôs unclear if ByteDance will transfer TikTok‚Äôs recommendation algorithm to the new U.S. version.
The switchover could disrupt ad targeting, follower retention, and algorithm-driven engagement ‚Äî a potential blow to creators and brands.

Amid the ongoing U.S.-China standoff, Trump has extended the TikTok ban, pushing the sell-by deadline to September 17. A potential buyout could top $50B. Now, the fate of TikTok‚Äôs 170M U.S. users rests on whether a stripped-down version can survive, potentially without its core algorithm.
Image source: Steve Jennings/Getty Images for TechCrunch/Wikimedia Commons
OpenAI has significantly tightened its security measures amid rising concerns over intellectual property theft, following the January release of a rival open-source AI model by DeepSeek, the
OpenAI‚Äôs overhaul includes biometric access controls and a ‚Äúdeny-by-default‚Äù internet policy that requires explicit approval for any external connections.
Proprietary tech is now isolated on offline systems, and only a tightly vetted group of employees can access or even discuss certain projects.
OpenAI claims DeepSeek used ‚Äúdistillation‚Äù methods to extract knowledge from its models through structured API queries, breaching usage terms.
In response, the AI giant now has stricter verification for API access, requiring government-issued IDs to unlock advanced features.

OpenAI is seriously locking down the lab to protect its $300B AI powerhouse as concerns rise about Chinese corporate espionage. In the AI arms race, it‚Äôs not just outsiders they‚Äôre likely worried about ‚Äî it‚Äôs loose lips and poaching from their own backyard as well.
raised $250M in a Series A round of funding for its night-vision and optical zoom contact lens.
sales event is
to boost online spending to an eye-watering $23.9B, a 28.4% increase from last year.
robotaxi testing in Philadelphia and NYC, deploying sensor-equipped vehicles to map and collect data as it explores expanding its service.
, the maker of Fortnite,
withdrew its antitrust lawsuit against Samsung after the two companies reached an undisclosed settlement.
from Mistral, ASML, Airbus, and others have
that the European Commission delay enforcing its landmark AI act for two years.
is
a ‚Ç¨500M ($587M) EU fine for allegedly breaching new Big Tech regulations.
is
to begin assembling EVs at its new Brazilian factory as early as this month, aiming to cut imports as rising tariffs impact its largest overseas market.
has
a major round of layoffs, notifying employees individually this week, with reports indicating that thousands of jobs are on the line.
it plans to buy Core Scientific, a data center infrastructure operator, in a reported all-stock deal valued at $9B.
